case_vignette:
A 32-year-old Caucasian man presents to the physician because of the swelling and discomfort of the right testis for 3 weeks. There is no history of trauma, fever, or night sweats. He had surgery for an undescended right testis when he was 6 months old. There is no history of liver disease or hypogonadism. He has fathered 2 children. He takes no medications and denies any illicit drug use. The vital signs are within normal limits. Palpation of the scrotum reveals a firm nontender mass that cannot be separated from the right testis. Examination of the left testis shows no abnormalities. There is no supraclavicular or inguinal lymphadenopathy. Gynecomastia is present. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Ultrasound shows an enlarged right testicle with a hypoechoic mass replacing a large portion of the normal architecture. The left testis is normal. The laboratory test results are as follows:
HCG Elevated
AFP Elevated
LDH Normal
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

I've been experiencing swelling and discomfort in my right testicle for the past 3 weeks.

No, I haven't felt any pain or discomfort in my lower abdomen or groin area, other than the discomfort in my right testicle.

I haven't noticed any changes in my semen production or quality.
Great, that helps to rule out some potential causes. Have you had any recent illnesses or infections, such as a urinary tract infection or a cold?
No, I haven't had any recent illnesses or infections like a urinary tract infection or a cold.

Okay, that's good to know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to perform a physical examination to further evaluate your condition. Can you please remove your clothing from the waist down and lie on the examination table?
I'm just here to talk about my symptoms; I can't actually go through an examination or remove any clothing.

Of course, I understand. Based on the information you've provided, it's possible that you may have a condition such as epididymitis, which is an inflammation of the epididymis, a small tube located at the back of the testicle. This can be caused by a bacterial infection, usually from a urinary tract infection, or a sexually transmitted infection.

I would recommend that you see a healthcare provider for further evaluation and diagnosis. They may perform a physical examination, take a medical history, and perform diagnostic tests such as a urinalysis or a blood test to determine the cause of your symptoms.

In the meantime, you can try applying a warm compress to your scrotum to help relieve any discomfort. If you experience any severe symptoms such as fever, chills, or difficulty urinating, you should seek medical attention immediately.

Please let me know if you have any other questions or concerns.
